The preponderance of comments here show complete ignorance of the sexism that existed throughout most of the 20th century. My mother was denied her divorce petition by the judge, who said "and how will you be able to support your children?". When I was 19 and working at a major food company that paid for its employees to go to school, I was turned down for photography because "a girl wouldn't be able to carry the equipment". (My super-slender ga y> guy friend was approved for the same class). Our classified ads were divided into "Help Wanted: Female" and "Help Wanted: Male". The female pages were entirely filled with secretarial and waitressing jobs. In high school, I wanted to play the drums for my music curriculum. I was told "you can't play the drums – you're a girl!" When I was 18 I went down to the newspaper to sub for my 13 ye ar old brother (who managed a newsstand) when he was sick one day. The cigar-smoking circulation manager and a roomful of boys laughed me right out.. "imagine, a girl selling newspapers! hahaha!" I had many jobs – and all of them had male bosses. I never even sa w a woman doctor, dentist, or cab driver (to name a few) until my late 30's. Men were pretty much given free rein to beat their wives. In many case s, a woman couldn't make a major purchase without her husband's signature. I haven't even scratched the surface to give you an inkling of the discrimination females (o f any age) faced every single day – I just wanted to list a few instances off the top of my head. It is an entirely different world today for females, who can pretty much do anything they want to do, and are not pressured by society to wait on men hand and foot, and to "shut up and look pretty".

commentThread.commentText: Damn, that's sick!

I was born and raised post-WWII (a Baby Boomer).  I remember those commercials and my disgust and disdain for them and the life they portrayed.  Thankfully, I had a father and male cousins who encouraged me in my (then) almost heretical view of "woman's lot".  I made up my mind that I would graduate high school (in the 1960s, dropping out to marry or get a job to help support your parents and siblings was somewhat acceptable) and earn a college degree.  Now in my seventh decade, I hold two degrees (one in mechanical engineering--the leading edge of so-called "liberated" women), three teaching credentials, and more certfications than I can count.  Now retired, I look back on a life that was lived MY WAY (apologies to Frank Sinatra) and was secure in the knowledge that, if I had to, I could support myself and my children comfortably.  While I horrified most of the women in my family, I had an aunt who applauded my independence along with my father and those wonderful male cousins who knew that a girl didn't have to be bound by her ability to make great coffee (I can), cook wholesome as well as gourmet meals (I can), and keep house (okay, I hate that part)  as well as bring home the high-quality bacon.

Tony, most men cannot possibly understand the frustration of intelligent and well-educated women when faced with sexism in American culture. I didn't get a 50% cut in my college tuition when I earned my engineering degree (late 1960s), but I was expected to accept 50% of the salary paid to the kid at the drafting table behind me with a vocational-technical certificate from high school. I was expected to endure the patronizing pats on the head by chief engineers when, protesting the salary inequity, I was told not to worry, that some man would marry me and take me away from all this. I couldn't get a charge account unless my father agreed to co-sign it, although my landlord expected his rent from me, as did the light company, the water company, the gas company, and the grocery store. I couldn't buy a car without my father's consent, although I wa s old enough to vote. A woman who got pregnant out of wedlock was at the mercy of her boyfriend's decision whether or not to marry her--and, if she chose to sue for child support, all he had to do was find 3 friends to say they took turns with him that night and he was free and clear of paternity. My life is NOT circumscribed or determined by the men in it. I love my father, who encouraged all that independence--which was unheard of for a girl of my day or a father who was Eastern European by ethnicity. Women of my generation revolted against such inequity, and rightly so. What man would tolerate second-class citizenship like that which women endured? What father worth the name could possibly stand by and watch that happen to his daughter without rising in righteous anger at a society that would permit it?

Change is inevitable and in various instances greatly desired...and needed!

They were called "The Greatest Generation" by Tom Brokaw due to his book by the same title. In point of fact, the 50s and 60s parents were born and raised during the Great Depression and WW II. They endured poverty, joblessness, hunger (my own father tells of frying homemade bread on top of a coal stove "buttered" with lard as they had no frying pan), deprivation, and lack of upward mobility not to mention hope for a future. Then they lived through WW II fought on two fronts and burdened with rationing coupons, blackout curtains (my high school still used them when showing filmstrips in classes), gasoline rationing ( doctors were among the few with A stickers on their cars allowing them pretty much unlimited gas purchases). Post WW II, the wartime industries geared up to produce goods and services that were unattainable by most in the previous two decades such as appliances, clothing (look at vintage patterns to see how fabric was

used almost to excess, especially in little girls' dresses).  Plastics began to be used in toys, not military equipment.  Steel was used in cars, not ships or planes.  Madison Avenue (advertising) extolled the virtues of homemaking in a peaceful (for five years, anyway until the Korean Conflict of 1950) economy.

commentThread.commentText: So, let me think about this.  In the first clip her coffee actually KILLED the plants, and HE wasn't supposed to say anything about how bad it was?  That silence would lead to her improving it, how?  In the next few it is suggested that a woman attempt to always look her best--Tab was a DIET drink, remember?--so that he would be proud to be seen with her.  Compared to modern day when you are out with sweat hogs in stretch pants, no make up, hair not done, shoes rundown...yeah, I see how suggesting that one 'fix herself up' when out in public could be 'oppressive'.  So the take away here is, guys, don't waste your time worrying about your wife's safety when she drives alone.  Guys, don't look to have any pride in the woman you have or intend to marry--just be grateful that she has a pulse.  Yikes, times have changed, and no, not for the best.

The most sexist part was not until you quit the countdown! How funny!
#1 - Fur coat payments. Really? Is that all you've got? From actually sexist decades, this is the best you can do?
#2 - the purse thing? WTF? You show 4 seconds - how is anyone to know WTF is going on?

So, it is sexist to tell a woman that men will be attracted to good coffee makers, but to make an ad implying that a man with some nasty grease in his hair will attract women is sexist. Got it! Next...

#6 - yes, men who have bought flowers for their anniversary ALWAYS say stupid shit like that, and their wives respond a few hours later with, "Sorry, but my coffee was to awful to drink, so I am too tired for sex now." Again, this guy was less of an ass than the first, but it is the MAN being unrealistically and unflatteringly portrayed - not the woman. The ad is designed to play on her worst fears about men and portrays them as if they are real. Verdict - sexist - towards men.

#5 - Is the same as every ad for razors, body sprays, clothes, cars and almost anything I can think of that is targeted at men TODAY! She wants you to smell good, look good, have a close shave, drink the right beer, drive the right car, etc. Once again, I call bullshit.

#5 - Gee! A flour company encouraging housewives to BAKE more! Who would have thought?!!! If this were not sexist, they would have had a man doing the baking, even though few men even today are interested in baking, and far fewer then! What next? It's sexist to make Barbie ads to appeal to girls?
#4 - sexist both ways! The man is an ass, and the woman is stupid.

#3 - slightly sexist. But at the time, almost ALL office assistants were women, and most still are. The point of this ad is not that women are clueless dolts, but that even a clueless dolt can be indispensable if he/she has a Xerox copier available. So again, I call bullshit.

#2 - targeted to men. And like #1 playing on the worst fears. I know it is terrible for a man to worry about the safety of his wife (especially when she is alone) but can we be forgiven for that? No matter how good a driver your wife is, driving in a car without safety glass is dangerous! So, is it sexist for men to be willing to spend a bunch of money to keep the person he loves most safe? I say no.

#1 - who is the douchebag here? The man.Of course, no halfway decent man in the 20th century ever behaved that way, but the advertisers played on the fears ans desires of women by portraying all the worst fears of men. So I agree - sexist - against  men.

These are funny, but what is funnier is that you left out the thousands of ads in which men are told that they will not be acceptable to women if they lack the right razor, cologne, after shave, car, beer, or clothes! Apparently, when advertisers appeal to insecurity in sexual relationships, it's only sexist one way! Oh, wait! I am wrong! All of the ads, including those I mentioned, are sexist against WOMEN! Telling men that they had better use AXE body spray, or be ignored by women is different from telling women that they should use another brand of coffee.
Are people happier today where no one has distinct roles to play out?

replies.commentText: @Althea Actually, that's been debunked several times. The reason women make less on average isn't because society has it in for women, but because (a) they tend to take less dangerous and less skilled jobs which pay less and (b) they get pregnant and take time off from work. One of the "war on women" sources actually compared a man and women in the same field, but in different jobs. For instance, a secretary and a geologist may both work for the same oil company, but she's going to make less than he does and it would be unreasonable to pay a secretary the same as a geologist.

Capitalism was missing an analysis of usury.  There is a huge confusion regarding the word "capitalism".  IMO, most people confuse "capitalism" with the market system and juxtapose the word "capitalism" against "socialism".  I think this leads to a lot of confusion.

From my readings, Adam Smith, who is deemed the "father of capitalism" never used the word.  Early usage of the word "capitalism" was used to describe the financial sector.  It wasn't until Karl Marx used the term that "capitalism" took on a different meaning.

Marx pretty much labels any and all market activity as "capitalist".  IMO this was deliberate in order to create a strawman and to confuse people about the market function.

Marx, who has a relative connection to the Rothschild usury sought to shift the focus away from the banking class and towards the industrial (productive) class.  

As I stated previously, Marxists loathe the Middle Class (bourgeoises) and the entrepreneurial class.  It is from these two classes that poses the greatest threat to the bankers. 

Thus "capitalism" IMO becomes a catch-all term for anyone that engages in productive activity for profit.  It was Marx's way to attack industrialists and shift our attention away from usury.  In fact Marx goes so far as to attack the Catholic Church as benefitting from usury when in fact the church for centuries stood against it.

If you want a different take on Capitalism I recommend reading the works of E. Michael Jones.  He has a new book coming out called Barren Metal.  His take on Capitalism is to describe it as state sponsored usury.
